# Highest-paid NBA players by season

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The **highest-paid NBA players by season** over the past twelve seasons have
received contracts with salaries noted in the twenty-million-dollar range. In
this twelve-year span, [Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett")
received $28,000,000, which was the highest salary payment of any NBA player,
during the [2003–04 season](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_NBA_season "2003–04 NBA
season"). Garnett has been the highest-paid [NBA](/wiki/NBA "NBA") player per
year in seven of the past twelve NBA seasons. [Michael
Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan") was the first NBA player to
sign a contract worth over thirty million dollars in a season. During the
[1997–98 season](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_NBA_season "1997–98 NBA season"),
Jordan earned $33,000,000. [Kobe Bryant](/wiki/Kobe_Bryant "Kobe Bryant")
become just the second player to reach this milestone when the [2013–14
season](/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_NBA_season "2013–14 NBA season") began.[1]
[LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") became the third in the
[2016–17 season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_NBA_season "2016–17 NBA season").
[Stephen Curry](/wiki/Stephen_Curry "Stephen Curry") became the first player
to eclipse $40-Million per year when he signed a record 5-year contract worth
$201-Million in 2017.

Beginning in the [1984–85 NBA season](/wiki/1984%E2%80%9385_NBA_season
"1984–85 NBA season"), the NBA's first salary cap was introduced. The [NBA
salary cap](/wiki/NBA_salary_cap "NBA salary cap") is the maximum dollar
amount each NBA team can spend on its players for the season. However, the NBA
uses a "soft" salary cap, which means that significant "salary exceptions"
allow NBA teams to exceed their allotted amount in order to sign players. The
salary cap is determined during the [offseason](/wiki/Offseason "Offseason"),
but as stated earlier, it is liable to change.[2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Jordan_by_Lipofsky_16577.jpg/225px-
Jordan_by_Lipofsky_16577.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jordan_by_Lipofsky_16577.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jordan_by_Lipofsky_16577.jpg "Enlarge")

[Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan"), who earned
$33,000,000 in the [1997–98 NBA season](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_NBA_season
"1997–98 NBA season"), attempts a [slam dunk](/wiki/Slam_dunk "Slam dunk") at
the old [Boston Garden](/wiki/Boston_Garden "Boston Garden").

An exception is necessary to sign a player for a contract that would exceed
the salary cap threshold of the "soft cap". The [Larry Bird
exception](/wiki/Larry_Bird_exception "Larry Bird exception"), more commonly
known as Bird Rights, allows teams to re-sign a current player only if he has
played for that particular team for a minimum of three years.[3] Another
exception known as the mid-level exception allows for teams that are over the
salary cap to sign one or more players as long as they do not exceed the total
amount of the average NBA salary.[4] Next, the bi-annual exception can be used
by teams every other year to sign a free agent(s) for up to two years at an
amount set by the NBA.[5] Finally, the rookie player exception allows any NBA
team to sign their first-round draft pick to a contract based upon a scale
previously set forth by the NBA. Another option for teams would be to assign
players to a league-assigned minimum salary contract for a maximum of two
years.

According to [2010–11 NBA season](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_NBA_season "2010–11
NBA season") game performance, the league's best players were not its highest-
paid players. Each year there are ten players selected to one of the two [All-
NBA Teams](/wiki/All-NBA_Team "All-NBA Team"). Out of those ten players chosen
that year, [Kobe Bryant](/wiki/Kobe_Bryant "Kobe Bryant") was the only player
that was also among the game's ten highest-paid during the 2010–11 NBA
season.[6]
